title: How to Cook with Cricket Flour

steps.headline: Understand that cricket flour is a little hard to come by.
steps.description: Most grocery stores aren't stocking their shelves with it, and unfortunately it can be a little pricey. However, on the wonderful world wide web, nothing is beyond your reach.

steps.headline: Search for cricket flour on your web browser.
steps.description: You can buy any brand you like and in any increment. Just make sure that you are buying 100% pure cricket flour.

steps.headline: Gather your ingredients and materials.
steps.description:
For this recipe, you'll need:
4 cups of mashed potatoes (instant or homemade, fresh or leftovers -- any is fine)
2 tablespoons of milk
1 to 2 green onions, chopped finely
2 egg yolks
3 to 4 tablespoons cricket flour
1 tablespoon whole wheat flour
1 whole egg
4 to 5 cups bread crumbs
Salt and pepper to taste
Peanut oil

steps.headline: Combine the mashed potatoes, milk, 1/2 tablespoon of green onions, egg yolks, 3 tablespoons of cricket flour, and salt and pepper together in a bowl.
Mix until the ingredients are blended and set in your refrigerator for 30 to 45 minutes.
Begin to prepare your frying station right before the mashed mix is ready to come out.
Add 1/2 inch of peanut oil to your frying pan and place over medium-high heat.
steps.description: Your oil will get very hot. The proper frying temperature for your oil should be around 350°F (180°C). If you have a candy or cooking thermometer, you can use this to monitor your oil. Another alternative is to dip the end of a wooden object (e.g. a spoon or chopstick)  in the oil. If the oil lightly bubbles, then you are good to go.

steps.headline: Beat the single, whole egg and place in a small dish.
steps.description: This will be your egg wash.

steps.headline: In another dish, combine bread crumbs and 1 tablespoon of whole wheat flour for your breading mixture.
steps.description: You may substitute the whole wheat flour for 1 tablespoon of cricket flour if you prefer.

steps.headline: Remove the chilled mashed potato mix from the refrigerator and roll into 1 inch (2.5cm) balls.
Dip the balls into your egg wash first, lightly coating the entire surface.
Transfer to bread crumb mixture and roll around until completely covered.
steps.description: Using a fork to do this step may help keep your fingers clean and clump-free.

steps.headline: If your oil is ready to go, slowly and carefully add your croquettes to your pan.
steps.description: Add them one at a time using the tongs to reduce your chances of getting burned. Keep in mind that you don't want to overcrowd your frying pan. You should leave about 1.5 to 2 inches (3.8 to 5cm) in between each ball for the best cooking results.

steps.headline: Fry each side until golden brown.
steps.description: Your entire frying time should not exceed 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Once all sides are finished cooking, slowly remove each ball one at a time from the pan and onto a plate.
steps.description: You should lined this plate with paper towel to help soak up any excess oil.

steps.headline: Continue to fry each croquette until all of your mashed potato mixture is gone.
Allow the croquettes to cool for 8 to 10 minutes and enjoy!
steps.description: You can garnish these with some chopped chives, parmesan cheese, or sour cream!

text:
Finding Cricket Flour Understand that cricket flour is a little hard to come by. Most grocery stores aren't stocking their shelves with it, and unfortunately it can be a little pricey. However, on the wonderful world wide web, nothing is beyond your reach. Search for cricket flour on your web browser. You can buy any brand you like and in any increment. Just make sure that you are buying 100% pure cricket flour. Cricket Croquette Recipe Gather your ingredients and materials. For this recipe, you'll need:
4 cups of mashed potatoes (instant or homemade, fresh or leftovers -- any is fine)
2 tablespoons of milk
1 to 2 green onions, chopped finely
2 egg yolks
3 to 4 tablespoons cricket flour
1 tablespoon whole wheat flour
1 whole egg
4 to 5 cups bread crumbs
Salt and pepper to taste
Peanut oil Combine the mashed potatoes, milk, 1/2 tablespoon of green onions, egg yolks, 3 tablespoons of cricket flour, and salt and pepper together in a bowl.  Mix until the ingredients are blended and set in your refrigerator for 30 to 45 minutes.  Begin to prepare your frying station right before the mashed mix is ready to come out.  Add 1/2 inch of peanut oil to your frying pan and place over medium-high heat. Your oil will get very hot. The proper frying temperature for your oil should be around 350°F (180°C). If you have a candy or cooking thermometer, you can use this to monitor your oil. Another alternative is to dip the end of a wooden object (e.g. a spoon or chopstick)  in the oil. If the oil lightly bubbles, then you are good to go. Beat the single, whole egg and place in a small dish. This will be your egg wash. In another dish, combine bread crumbs and 1 tablespoon of whole wheat flour for your breading mixture. You may substitute the whole wheat flour for 1 tablespoon of cricket flour if you prefer. Remove the chilled mashed potato mix from the refrigerator and roll into 1 inch (2.5cm) balls.  Dip the balls into your egg wash first, lightly coating the entire surface.  Transfer to bread crumb mixture and roll around until completely covered. Using a fork to do this step may help keep your fingers clean and clump-free. If your oil is ready to go, slowly and carefully add your croquettes to your pan. Add them one at a time using the tongs to reduce your chances of getting burned. Keep in mind that you don't want to overcrowd your frying pan. You should leave about 1.5 to 2 inches (3.8 to 5cm) in between each ball for the best cooking results. Fry each side until golden brown. Your entire frying time should not exceed 10 minutes. Once all sides are finished cooking, slowly remove each ball one at a time from the pan and onto a plate. You should lined this plate with paper towel to help soak up any excess oil. Continue to fry each croquette until all of your mashed potato mixture is gone.  Allow the croquettes to cool for 8 to 10 minutes and enjoy! You can garnish these with some chopped chives, parmesan cheese, or sour cream!
